POR.DRECONTENT:
Big Data in medicine and public health provides a new opportunity to learn about causes of disease, treatments for disease, and to predict health outcomes. However, the deluge of data information must be sifted through carefully, following guiding principles in statistics while using new tools, to avoid incorrect conclusions.  Work completed during this postdoctoral fellowship period explored estimating causal effects in study populations where, for example, there is a rare disease, as well as scientific discovery in the area of machine learning -- using automated procedures to explore data -- to predict health outcomes.  Both of these statistical areas are crucial in the new era of Big Data.  The combination of machine learning, causal inference, and statistical principles allows us to explore state-of-the-art techniques while remaining grounded in a theoretical framework.  That is to say, we unite the best of the applied and theoretical worlds to have a positive impact on public health tools for scientific discovery. For example, the research generated during the postdoctoral fellowship produced a new formula for predicting mortality in the elderly. [This postdoctoral award mechanism was designed to "support future leaders in mathematics and statistics by facilitating their participation in postdoctoral research environments that will have maximal impact on their future scientific development."]
